articles.headline: What New Rules on Retirement Savings Mean for Investors
articles.snippet: Some answers to common questions about the Labor Department’s new rules.
articles.abstract: Some answers to common questions about the Labor Department’s new rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department introduced new rules on Wednesday that will help protect Americans saving for retirement. While investors often assume those handling their savings are providing advice in their best interest, that is not always the case. Here is how things will change.

articles.headline: Reddit Steps Up Anti-Harassment Measures With New Blocking Tool
articles.snippet: The discussion site is hoping that less negative speech will encourage users to engage more with the community.
articles.abstract: The discussion site is hoping that less negative speech will encourage users to engage more with the community.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since 2005, Reddit has been a veritable wonderland for the most extreme forms of free speech on the Internet.

articles.headline: Fed Still Waving Caution Flag on Resuming Interest Rate Increases
articles.snippet: Expectations are growing that the Fed’s policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, will not seriously consider lifting interest rates until June.
articles.abstract: Expectations are growing that the Fed’s policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, will not seriously consider lifting interest rates until June.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials not only decided against raising interest rates at their most recent meeting in March, but they also came close to ruling out an increase at their next meeting this month.

articles.headline: Fintech Firms Are Taking On the Big Banks, but Can They Win?
articles.snippet: A spate of mergers and acquisitions that puts the disrupters squarely inside the institutions they were supposed to overtake is one possible outcome of the fintech frenzy.
articles.abstract: A spate of mergers and acquisitions that puts the disrupters squarely inside the institutions they were supposed to overtake is one possible outcome of the fintech frenzy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banking has long been viewed as one of the last traditional, old-school, stuck-in-the-past industries. When you think of banking, you might still think of wood-paneled walls and pinstripe suits.

articles.headline: Facebook Groups Act as Weapons Bazaars for Militias
articles.snippet: Facebook posts suggest evidence of large-scale efforts to buy and sell weapons as large as guided missiles in the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.abstract: Facebook posts suggest evidence of large-scale efforts to buy and sell weapons as large as guided missiles in the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: A terrorist hoping to buy an antiaircraft weapon in recent years needed to look no further than Facebook, which has been hosting sprawling online arms bazaars, offering weapons ranging from handguns and grenades to heavy machine guns and guided missiles.

articles.headline: Megamergers Face Deterrents in the United States
articles.snippet: The Obama administration took on two possible deals this week, and claimed a victory with one.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration took on two possible deals this week, and claimed a victory with one.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drug giant Pfizer wanted to cut its taxes through a $152 billion takeover of the Dublin-based maker of Botox. And Halliburton sought to buy a major rival in the business of selling equipment to oil drillers for nearly $35 billion.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Again Looks Upstate for Win in New York
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s Senate victory was fueled by the unlikely support of white working-class voters there, but she faces new challenges in securing that kind of support again.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s Senate victory was fueled by the unlikely support of white working-class voters there, but she faces new challenges in securing that kind of support again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s political ascent can be traced to the time in 1999 when she expressed her support for dairy farmers in the upstate New York village of Endicott. And the summer that year when she shunned Martha’s Vineyard to vacation in Skaneateles, and promised voters in the depleted industrial city of Schenectady that as a New York senator she would revive the upstate economy.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Panama Papers Leak Casts Light on a Law Firm Founded on Secrecy
articles.snippet: Ramón Fonseca, a co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, proclaimed his firm’s innocence. But some say the leak’s contents are at odds with how he has tried to portray himself and his role in Panama.
articles.abstract: Ramón Fonseca, a co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, proclaimed his firm’s innocence. But some say the leak’s contents are at odds with how he has tried to portray himself and his role in Panama.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The two men came together in an era of political and economic uncertainty in Panama: One a reserved German immigrant whose father served in the armed wing of the Nazi party, the other a gregarious, aspiring novelist whose family opposed Panama’s military dictatorship.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple, Azam Ahmed and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: G.O.P. Donors, Eager to Defeat Donald Trump, Learn to Love Ted Cruz
articles.snippet: Of all the alliances being forged over opposition to Mr. Trump’s bid for the nomination, few are as unlikely as that of Mr. Cruz and his party’s elite donor establishment.
articles.abstract: Of all the alliances being forged over opposition to Mr. Trump’s bid for the nomination, few are as unlikely as that of Mr. Cruz and his party’s elite donor establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nestled in the neo-Georgian sanctuary of the Knickerbocker Club, one of New York’s oldest and fustiest social establishments, a select group of Republican donors gathered late last month to take up an unexpected task: reconsidering Ted Cruz.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: China Stanches Flow of Money Out of the Country, Data Suggests
articles.snippet: Officials said that the country’s hoard of foreign exchange reserves, a rough proxy for money moving in and out of the nation, grew in March for the first time in five months.
articles.abstract: Officials said that the country’s hoard of foreign exchange reserves, a rough proxy for money moving in and out of the nation, grew in March for the first time in five months.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China rattled markets around the world last year when vast sums of money began flowing out of the country. Estimated at nearly $1 trillion, the money flows represented growing skepticism that China would be able to fix its deep problems and resume its place as a driver of global economic growth.

articles.headline: Boko Haram Turns Female Captives Into Terrorists
articles.snippet: Of all the many horrors of Boko Haram’s rampage, one of the most baffling has been its ability to turn captured women and girls into killers.
articles.abstract: Of all the many horrors of Boko Haram’s rampage, one of the most baffling has been its ability to turn captured women and girls into killers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINAWAO REFUGEE CAMP, Cameroon — Hold the bomb under your armpit to keep it steady, the women and girls were taught.

articles.headline: Need to Hide Some Income? You Don’t Have to Go to Panama
articles.snippet: Setting up a shell corporation in the United States is simple — especially in states like Delaware, Wyoming and Nevada.
articles.abstract: Setting up a shell corporation in the United States is simple — especially in states like Delaware, Wyoming and Nevada.
articles.lead_paragraph: For wealthy Americans looking to veil their assets and shield some of their income from taxation, there is no need to go to Panama or any other offshore tax haven. It’s easy to establish a shell corporation right here at home.
